Legal_Provision_Violated: Failure to correctly apply scoring under Independent or Assisted Relative category
Application_Facts: Applicant assessed as assisted relative; scored 61 units with 5-unit bonus; errors in occupation, personal suitability, and funds sufficiency assessments
Procedural_Issue: Assessment errors in occupation, personal suitability, and funds; refusal letter incorrectly cited independent category
Evidence_Used: Assessment score, officer's evaluation of occupation, personal suitability, financial sufficiency
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inaccurate scoring, incorrect application of category criteria
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; original refusal invalidated
Legal_Standard_Applied: Minimum point threshold: 65 for assisted relatives, 70 for independent immigrants
Decision_Rationale: Procedural errors and misapplication of category led to unfair refusal
Authority_Responsible: Immigration Officer (original decision); different Visa Officer on remand

Application_Facts: Applicant has 20 years of experience in the garment industry; visa officer assessed zero units for experience without analyzing job components or transferable skills; applicant faced language difficulties
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide fair assessment
Lack of specific inquiry into relevant work history
No breakdown of job duties or transferable skills considered
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer did not request additional details or clarification on work experience despite language barriers
Decision_Outcome: Visa denied due to perceived lack of relevant experience as a production line manager
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of visa application by a different officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Duty of fairness in administrative decision-making
Proper assessment of related work experience under immigration regulations
Decision_Rationale: Visa officer erred in law by failing to fairly assess applicant's extensive work experience and breached duty of fairness; decision not based on full consideration of relevant factors

Legal_Issue: Did the visa officer improperly refuse the applicant's request for permanent residence by misclassifying his occupation and failing to conduct a fair assessment?
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review via certiorari and mandamus
Evidence_Assessment: The visa officer failed to evaluate the applicant's work experience in the designated category (5133-126) despite evidence of relevant experience.
Decision_Outcome: The application succeeds; the visa officer's decision is set aside.
Legal_Rule: Under the Immigration Act and Regulations, visa officers must thoroughly assess applicants' qualifications and provide fair evaluations. Applicants have the right to frame their applications to maximize entry chances.
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness (implied by judicial review context)
Grounds_for_Claim: Misclassification of the applicant's occupation and failure to assess alternate occupations inherent in his work experience.
Outcome_on_Merits: The court found in favor of the applicant.
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's claimed experience as a 'Commercial Traveller', evidence of relevant experience in category 5133-126.
Remedy_Requested: Re-assessment of the applicant's case by a different visa officer
Outcome: The court ordered a re-assessment of the applicant's case by a different visa officer, ensuring compliance with immigration laws.
Authority: Visa officer, Court conducting judicial review

Crime_Name: Judicial Review of Visa Application Denial
Legal_Provision_Violated: Personal suitability assessment under economic factors
Application_Facts: Applicant lacked savings and ignored modern bookkeeping methods; jewelry was not liquid and irrelevant
Procedural_Issue: Assessment of motivation and adaptability during interview
Evidence_Used: Lack of assets, absence of computer skills, interview responses
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide proof of financial stability or technological adaptability
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found poor motivation based on lack of preparation and outdated practices
Legal_Standard_Applied: Assessment of personal suitability including economic motivation and adaptability
Decision_Rationale: Officer validly considered lack of assets and computer skills as indicators of poor motivation and adaptability

Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer erred in law by failing to consider the applicant's aptitude and future potential
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant's skills, experience, initiative, efforts to upgrade qualifications, bonus units, total score of 45/55
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate legal error by the visa officer
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's limited initiative and lack of qualification upgrades considered
Legal_Rule: Visa officer must assess skills, experience, and aptitudes; discretion allowed under Section 11(3) if units don't reflect establishment chances
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged failure to consider aptitude and future potential
Outcome_on_Merits: No legal error found in the visa officer's assessment
Key_Evidence_Considered: Job-related skills, experience, initiative, qualification upgrades, scoring under immigration system
Defendant_Response: Visa officer properly assessed all relevant factors including aptitude
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, application forms, scoring records
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of visa officer's decision

Application_Facts: Applicants claimed persecution and humanitarian protection.
Inconsistencies in applicants' story, including circumstances of husband's death.
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistencies in narrative suggesting potential misrepresentation
Procedural_Issue: Alleged procedural unfairness
Opportunity to respond was provided
Credibility_Assessment: Visa officer found applicants' story not credible
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness
Adequacy of reasons
Reasonableness of credibility determination
Decision_Rationale: Visa officer acted fairly.
Sufficient reasons were provided.
Credibility assessment was reasonable.
Applicants were given opportunity to address inconsistencies.

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Personalized risk claimed, assessed as generalized by Board
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Reasonable and consistent
Crimes.Legal_Provision: s. 97(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Personalized risk claimed, assessed as generalized by Board
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Reasonable and consistent
Crimes.Legal_Provision: s. 97(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Violation_Type: Abuse of power by state officials
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants victimized by police; claim of lack of state protection
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of Board's interpretation of personalized risk
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to adequately consider targeted nature of risk
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants found credible
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Risk was not generalized given repeated targeting by police

Application_Facts: Nandre was absent from Canada for significant periods but maintained ties such as property ownership and tax payments.
Residency_Compliance: Questionable; physical presence not met, qualitative test applied without clear determination of when residence was established
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge failed to determine when Nandre established residence in Canada
Evidence_Used: Property ownership, tax payments, periods of absence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of specific finding on when residence was established
Outcome: Citizenship application denied due to insufficient proof of residency
Legal_Standard_Applied: Three years of residence in Canada during the previous four years; interpretation of 'residence' via physical or qualitative test
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge did not specify when Nandre established residence, which is essential to assess compliance with s. 5(1). The failure to make this determination constitutes an error in law.

Violation_Type: Refugee claim based on lack of well-founded fear of persecution
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution in Sri Lanka due to Tamil ethnicity; Board found no credible evidence linking fear to race or political opinion; incidents involved authorities and post-war extortion unrelated to Convention grounds
Procedural_Issue: Credibility assessment, linkage of evidence to Convention grounds
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, encounters with authorities, context of post-war Sri Lanka
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence connecting experiences to race or political opinion
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant's fear not credible or insufficiently linked to protected grounds
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied by the Refugee Protection Division
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of the denial and granting of refugee protection
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under Section 96
Decision_Rationale: No evidence established a link between the applicant's experiences and persecution based on race, religion, nationality, political opinion, or social group; incidents were attributed to general law enforcement or criminal activity
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB), Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Risk_Nature: persecution due to race and ethnicity

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Risk_Nature: discrimination based on race and ethnicity

Application_Facts: Roma family faced persecution in Hungary
Procedural_Issue: reasonableness of RPD's analysis
Legal_Standard_Applied: balance of probabilities
Decision_Rationale: RPD reasonably concluded inadequate state protection

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses

Crimes.Crime_Name: Police inaction or complicity in crimes against racial minorities
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in assessing credibility regarding alleged rape and fear of persecution
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant not credible due to delays in reporting and inconsistencies; mental health evidence considered insufficient
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Medical evidence (DID), narrative testimony
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution based on alleged rape
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies in narrative and delay in reporting
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found; medical evidence was considered but deemed insufficient
Crimes.Application_Factor: Mental health condition (DID) offered as explanation for inconsistencies

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Sexual assault by a police officer
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Perpetrator was a state actor (police officer)
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Applicant suffered from DID, which may affect memory and consistency
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Risk of persecution upon return to St-Vincent
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Gender-based violence and abuse of power
Crimes.Threat_Source: Police officer and potential state complicity
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, based on gender and prior assault
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence, medical records (DID)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubted due to delays and inconsistencies despite mental health diagnosis

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Aggravated sexual assault by a police officer
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Abuse of authority, vulnerability of victim
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Very high (aggravated assault by state actor)
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of re-victimization and persecution
Crimes.Threat_Source: Police officer and systemic failure to protect
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, based on gender and prior report to authorities
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Narrative testimony, medical evidence (DID)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not credible due to behavioral and narrative inconsistencies

Crimes.Crime_Name: Breach of Trust by Peace Officer
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credibility in refugee claim involving abuse by police
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board reasonably assessed credibility of rape allegation against a police officer
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Medical evidence (DID) considered but not determinative
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish credible basis for claim
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Delay in reporting, inconsistencies in account
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged rape by police officer and fear of return
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to lack of credibility
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Board provided transparent and justified reasoning
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Medical and testimonial evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial intervention to overturn negative decision

Crimes.Violation_Type: Alleged false testimony in refugee proceeding
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of judicial review over credibility findings
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroboration and internal inconsistencies
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubted but no proof of deliberate falsehood
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No evidence of intent to deceive; inconsistencies possibly due to trauma

Application_Facts: Applicant fled Mexico due to threats and assaults after reporting a drug transaction; reported incidents to authorities but received no protection
Procedural_Issue: Board Member incorrectly applied the legal standard by focusing on Mexico’s efforts rather than actual effectiveness of protection
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, reports of threats and assaults, lack of response from Mexican authorities
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to assess effectiveness of state protection in Mexico
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected by Board Member
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a refugee in Canada
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of refugee claim by a different Board Member
Legal_Standard_Applied: Balance of probabilities; adequacy and effectiveness of state protection
Decision_Rationale: Board failed to properly assess whether state protection was actually effective in Mexico; focus should be on effectiveness, not just existence of efforts
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Application_Facts: Applicants claimed insufficient state protection in Portugal due to domestic violence
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging the weight of evidence and interpretation of testimony by the Officer
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Reliance on general country conditions over specific testimonies
Decision_Outcome: Officer denied PRRA application based on availability of state protection in Portugal
Relief_Sought: Substantive relief to overturn PRRA denial
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard unless legal issues are separable
Decision_Rationale: Officer's reasoning was thorough and deferential given expertise; concluded state protection in Portugal was adequate

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to maintain temporary resident status
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA and IRPR - Failure to meet conditions for temporary residency or restoration
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants entered Canada to care for a sick relative; after her death, they applied for permanent residency and sought restoration of visitor status.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign nationals applying for permanent residency
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to expired status, but applied for restoration
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer failed to consider new temporary purpose for stay
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Evidence of application for permanent residency, intent to remain temporarily during processing
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer ignored evidence of new temporary purpose
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Remission for redetermination by a different officer
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement of temporary purpose under IRPA/IRPR
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer erred by focusing solely on original purpose and not considering ongoing temporary purpose during PR application

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with conditions of temporary resident status
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration status and compliance with conditions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer properly assessed the existence of a temporary purpose for stay
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicants provided evidence of pending permanent residency application as basis for continued stay
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Denial of restoration of temporary resident status
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate intent to leave at end of authorized stay
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicants' stated intention to await permanent residency processing
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Intent to apply for permanent residency does not preclude temporary resident status if there is a genuine temporary purpose
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Officer failed to consider updated circumstances and applicable legal provisions
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Pending sponsorship application, duration of processing, original entry purpose
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA and IRPR provisions on temporary residence and restoration
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Officer emphasized original purpose being fulfilled and length of processing time
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of application, affidavits, immigration records
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Remission for reconsideration by a different officer
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 18(1) IRPA – Temporary Resident Status; Section 180 IRPR – Restoration of status

Violation_Type: Refugee claim denial based on lack of objective fear and internal flight alternative
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 72(1)
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution due to political affiliation but provided insufficient evidence; Lahore was assessed as a viable Internal Flight Alternative (IFA)
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of the Board's decision for reasonableness
Evidence_Used: Board's assessment of applicant's testimony and country condition evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to establish well-founded fear of persecution or unreasonableness of relocating to Lahore
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected by the Board
Relief_Sought: Overturning of the Board's decision rejecting refugee claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Applicant must prove risk of persecution or unreasonable relocation within country
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, considering justification, transparency, and intelligibility
Decision_Rationale: Board's conclusion that applicant failed to demonstrate objective fear and that Lahore was a viable IFA was reasonable

Application_Facts: Discrepancies in the applicant's testimony were attributed to translation problems between Yoruba and Igbo interpreters.
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to consider translation issues when assessing credibility.
Evidence_Used: Testimony of the applicant, interpreter services (Yoruba and Igbo)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD did not address potential translation errors despite explanations from the applicant.
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant not credible due to contradictions without considering translation issues; assessment deemed unreasonable.
Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by a differently constituted RPD
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard
Decision_Rationale: Failure to consider translation issues rendered credibility assessment unreasonable.

Legal_Provision_Violated: Principle of Procedural Fairness in Refugee Protection Division proceedings
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 101(1)(a)
Application_Facts: Applicants' refugee claims were dismissed based on perceived lack of evidence rebutting the presumption of state protection
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to question applicants about key documentary evidence; did not allow response to adverse information
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence submitted by applicants, hearing transcripts, RPD decision reasons
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD inadequately addressed contradictory evidence provided by applicants
Remedy_Sought: Remittal to a differently constituted RPD for redetermination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness under administrative law
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with respect to procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: RPD breached procedural fairness by failing to properly consider evidence and permit applicant response

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of credibility findings
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies in testimony, lack of media reports, medical records, lawyer's letter

Crimes.Threat_Source: Government official after assault and threats

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk due to ongoing threats
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, due to resistance of advances

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim due to property damage and threats
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Unreasonable credibility assessment by Board
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Media coverage assumption, medical omissions, lawyer's letter

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board failed to consider reasonable explanations

Crimes.Legal_Issue: When does a determination of non-compliance with residency obligations become final under section 28 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 28
Crimes.Outcome: Deportation order upheld; application for judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus on procedural compliance
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Residency records, appeal timelines, immigration documentation
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 28, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Loss of permanent resident status due to failure to meet residency obligations
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Expiry of appeal period leading to finality of determination
Crimes.Application_Error: Initial failure to appeal within prescribed timeframe
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None noted; court focused on statutory interpretation
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Finality of administrative decisions under immigration law
Crimes.Application_Factor: Appeal extension granted but did not invalidate prior deportation order
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed; no question certified for appeal
Crimes.Authority: Immigration Division, Immigration Appeal Division (IAD), Federal Court

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with residency obligations
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 28, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa and failed to meet physical presence requirements
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent resident subject to residency obligations
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable; based on factual absence rather than false statements
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Late appeal and subsequent extension granted by IAD
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Validity of deportation order during pending appeal
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Travel records, residency history, appeal filings
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide timely evidence of residency compliance
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not central; decision based on documentary evidence
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Deportation order valid but suspended pending appeal
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Suspension or cancellation of deportation order
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Finality of determination after appeal period expires
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Determination becomes final upon expiry of appeal period; extension suspends but does not invalidate removal

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with residency obligation
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 28, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to reside in Canada for required 730 days within five years
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: None alleged; based on objective absence
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Timeliness of appeal and extension granted by IAD
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Enforceability of deportation order during appeal
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Residency logs, travel documents, immigration records
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documentation proving sufficient presence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not disputed; factual basis accepted
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal, certification of appeal question
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Finality occurs when appeal period expires; extension only suspends removal

Crimes.Crime_Name: Committing certain offences leading to deportation
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Deportation based on criminality and residency non-compliance
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Timing of 'final determination' under s.46(1)(b) IRPA
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s.46(1)(b)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Criminal record, residency history, appeal timelines
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On immigration authorities to prove non-compliance and finality
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Loss of permanent resident status upon final determination of non-compliance
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged premature enforcement of deportation order
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Criminal convictions, residency data, appeal status
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA provisions on criminal inadmissibility and residency
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Challenged finality of determination due to pending appeal
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Criminal records, immigration files, appeal decisions
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 46(1)(b), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Violation_Type: Failure to adequately assess economic establishment potential
Application_Facts: Applicant lacked English proficiency for her job
Applicant had substantial settlement funds
Applicant received a supportive employer letter
Visa officer focused only on language deficiencies
Procedural_Issue: Visa officer failed to consider all relevant factors in assessment
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to account for non-point-based indicators of economic establishment
Decision_Outcome: Immigration application refused due to insufficient points, primarily based on inadequate English proficiency
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard
Decision_Rationale: Points awarded may not be a sufficient indicator of economic establishment
Visa officer must consider alternative evidence when points are inadequate
Officer unreasonably ignored settlement funds and employer support

Application_Facts: Mr. Ryivuze held a high-ranking position in Burundi's government, knew about its crimes, and did not disassociate. His role contributed to government operations despite knowledge of atrocities.
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Used: Position in government, knowledge of crimes, failure to disassociate
Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious reasons to believe standard, lower than civil or criminal law
Decision_Rationale: Mr. Ryivuze was complicit by association due to his role, knowledge, and failure to disengage from a regime committing crimes against humanity

Legal_Issue: Concealment of identity as a Burundian civil servant in refugee application
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 72(1)
Evidence_Type: Documentary and circumstantial evidence of government affiliation
Basis_of_Claim: Exclusion due to misrepresentation and complicity
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Voluntary association with government committing atrocities and concealment of identity
Legal_Standard: Lower standard than civil or criminal law
Application_Factor: High-ranking government role, knowledge, lack of disassociation
Document_Fraud: Concealment of identity as a civil servant

Application_Facts: Applicant failed to achieve required technical qualifications despite multiple opportunities; medical and positive assessments were considered but not decisive
Claimant_Status: Member of the Canadian Armed Forces
Procedural_Issue: Initial procedural error by DPCOR in release process; corrected by Chief of Defence Staff (CDS)
Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether CDS had authority to approve release under QRO
Decision_Outcome: CDS approved release after review; procedural fairness upheld
Relief_Sought: Challenge to procedural fairness of release from Canadian Armed Forces
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness
Jurisdictional authority under QRO
Decision_Rationale: CDS reviewed all relevant factors, corrected prior error, and acted within jurisdiction; no breach of natural justice

Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Applicant joined AUC after losing cocaine and participated in violent activities
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Involvement with AUC, a designated terrorist organization
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Participation in violent activities under the AUC
Crimes.Target_Entity: Colombian government and civilians (implied by AUC's operations)
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Voluntary membership found by the Board
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Board assessed Applicant's duress claim as inconsistent with actions
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Actions post-joining inconsistent with claimed duress
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Duress defense dismissed due to lack of imminence and escape options
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Article 31 of the Rome Statute, Canadian case law, IRPA

Crimes.Crime_Name: Participating in activities of a terrorist group
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant joined AUC after losing cocaine, engaged in violence, later sought refugee status in Canada
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Immigration Division decision
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to prove duress elements: imminence, no alternative, proportionality
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Duress claim not credible due to inconsistent conduct
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Inadmissible due to participation in terrorist activities
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review to overturn inadmissibility finding
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Cancellation of deportation, recognition as refugee
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant failed to meet burden of proving duress; participation was voluntary
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court on judicial review

Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 18.1(4)(d) of the Federal Court Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to persecution in Mexico; Refugee Division found internal flight alternative to be reasonable; evidence about police presence in Toluca and psychological impact was not addressed
Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider critical evidence; lack of proper assessment of relocation expectation
Evidence_Used: Applicant's evidence regarding police vehicles in Toluca, psychological impact of persecution
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Refugee Division did not address key evidence on safety concerns outside Mexico City
Decision_Outcome: Original decision rejected claim based on internal flight alternative
Outcome: Decision set aside; case remitted for reconsideration by a new panel
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review; reassessment of refugee claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious possibility of persecution; reasonableness of internal flight alternative
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness; correctness for questions of law
Decision_Rationale: It was unreasonable to expect relocation without assessing risks in Toluca; failure to consider evidence rendered decision perversely
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequate consideration of factors in H&C application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Insufficient evidence for abuse, credible risk, or hardship
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of evidence exceeding normal expectations

Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Pannu overstayed her visa and applied for H&C relief
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Evidence_Used: Treatment as divorced woman in India
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Factors considered but not sufficient to meet threshold
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No legal error; decision within acceptable range

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequacy of officer’s consideration in H&C refusal
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Alleged ignored evidence not substantiated
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Hardship upon return to home country

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with deportation order
Crimes.Application_Facts: Third H&C application following deportation order
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Hardship not shown to be unusual or disproportionate
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer reasonably assessed claims
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Exemption from removal on H&C grounds
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Decision rational and within bounds of reasonableness

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Officer’s consideration of H&C factors after work permit expiry
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims assessed but not sufficient for relief
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of evidence meeting H&C threshold

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant entered Canada fraudulently, raising admissibility concerns
Procedural_Issue: Application for stay of deportation pending judicial review
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No new evidence supports irreparable harm beyond general deportation consequences
Legal_Standard_Applied: Tripartite test: serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Decision_Rationale: Lack of irreparable harm demonstrated; fraudulent entry affects admissibility

Legal_Issue: Whether stay of deportation should be granted after denial of permanent residency due to fraudulent entry
Credibility_Assessment: Spousal dependency not conclusively proven; prior risk assessments rejected
Evidence_Type: Prior risk assessments, spousal relationship evidence
Basis_of_Claim: Challenging denial of permanent residency based on fraudulent entry
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Insufficient evidence of irreparable harm beyond general consequences of deportation
Application_Error: Use of fraudulent document to enter Canada
Assessment_Standard: Tripartite test for stay: serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Legal_Standard: Serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Decision_Outcome: Application for stay of deportation dismissed
Document_Fraud: Entered Canada with a fraudulent document

Crime_Name: Refugee Claim and Pre-Removal Risk Assessment
Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA officer erred in not holding an oral hearing or ignoring documentary evidence
Evidence_Assessment: PRRA officer considered new evidence about relatives' experiences with Sunni extremists but did not assess it fully
Credibility_Factor: Credibility was central to the decision; new evidence materially affected the outcome
Legal_Rule: Oral hearing required if credibility is central and new evidence affects outcome
Outcome_on_Merits: No reviewable error materially affected the outcome
Key_Evidence_Considered: New evidence regarding relatives' experiences with Sunni extremists

Crimes.Crime_Name: Tax Evasion under the Excise Tax Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the CRA Assistant Commissioner erred in refusing to recommend tax remission
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: CRA considered non-compliance history and public interest factors
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show unreasonableness or procedural unfairness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's claim of financial hardship weighed against compliance history
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Remission may be granted if collection is unreasonable, unjust, or not in public interest
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Financial hardship and public interest due to infrastructure needs
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Non-compliance history, financial situation, treaty rights argument
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Section 23(2) of the Financial Administration Act and CRA remission guidelines
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CRA cited non-compliance and discretion under guidelines
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Financial records, compliance history, submissions on public interest

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to collect and remit Harmonized Sales Tax
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the CRA Assistant Commissioner erred in refusing to recommend tax remission
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Hardship claims balanced against non-compliance and broader implications
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate error or breach of fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Public interest arguments weighed against history of non-compliance
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Remission may be granted if collection is unreasonable, unjust, or not in public interest
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Financial hardship and public interest related to community infrastructure
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Treaty rights claims, financial impact, compliance record
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Section 23(2) of the Financial Administration Act and CRA remission guidelines
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CRA emphasized discretion and prior non-compliance
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Submissions on financial hardship, treaty rights, compliance data

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Provide Reliable Documents for Immigration Purposes
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer infringed natural justice by not allowing opportunity to clarify documentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Plaintiff's explanations found not credible
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 18.1 of the Federal Court Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Inadequate financial documentation and admission of tax evasion
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to provide reliable income documentation
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Burden of proof on applicant to demonstrate admissibility

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration Admissibility based on financial conduct
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer violated natural justice regarding financial disclosures
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove legitimate income sources
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Admission of tax evasion undermined credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Applicants must prove admissibility; officers not required to assist absent extrinsic evidence
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No request for additional time or interpreter made
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 18.1 of the Federal Court Act

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer failed to afford fairness in assessing fund origins and tax claims
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistent explanations about income sources
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 18.1 of the Federal Court Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Misrepresentation regarding fund origin and tax compliance
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Admission of tax evasion and lack of verifiable income proof
Crimes.Application_Error: Providing false or misleading information in application
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Fairness in evaluation without obligation to assist applicant

Legal_Issue: Were the Citizenship Judge's reasons for denying citizenship adequate under the Citizenship Act?
Outcome: Appeals granted, case sent back for rehearing with a different judge
Legal_Provision: Requirement to provide clear reasons to applicants and the Minister
Basis_of_Claim: Inadequate and conflicting reasons provided by the Citizenship Judge
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to enumerate evidence or explain conclusions
Application_Error: Conflicting reasons given to applicants and the Minister
Legal_Standard: Clear, transparent, and reviewable reasoning required under the Citizenship Act
Application_Factor: Procedural fairness and adequacy of reasons
Decision_Outcome: Denial of citizenship overturned; remanded for rehearing

Crimes.Crime_Name: Illegal stay in the United States and Theft
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in determining that the Applicant committed a serious non-political crime (theft) under Article 1F(b) of the Convention and Section 98 of IRPA?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Article 1F(b) of the Convention, Section 98 of IRPA
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant admitted stealing $1 million from a mafia member; lack of intent, balancing harm, and poverty were rejected as mitigating factors
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate unreasonableness of the Board's decision
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant’s claims of mitigating circumstances were not accepted
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Individuals who commit serious non-political crimes are excluded from refugee protection under Article 1F(b) and Section 98 of IRPA
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error by the Board in applying the law and assessing intent and mitigation
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Admission of theft, amount stolen ($1 million), source of funds (mafia member)
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International Refugee Protection framework and Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed lack of intent, argued poverty and danger as justifications
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial and documentary evidence regarding criminal act and flight
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certification of a legal question and overturning of exclusion decision
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed; exclusion from refugee status maintained
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 98 of IRPA, Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of proceeds of crime over $5000
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee status exclusion based on serious criminality
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Is the Applicant excluded from refugee status due to committing a serious non-political crime?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Article 1F(b) of the Convention, section 98 of IRPA
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Refugee claim assessment and subsequent judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant stole $1 million from a mafia member, knowing it was likely proceeds of crime
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to rebut presumption of seriousness of the crime
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: No credibility found in justification based on poverty or self-preservation
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Serious non-political crimes lead to automatic exclusion from refugee protection
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Argument that theft from organized crime should not constitute a serious crime for exclusion purposes
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Amount stolen ($1 million), nature of victim (organized crime member), knowledge that funds were illicit
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Canadian immigration and refugee law, international conventions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued moral justification and lack of alternative
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Admissions, context of flight, source of property
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Overturn exclusion and grant refugee protection
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 98 of IRPA, Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee protection due to prior criminal conduct
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in determining that the Applicant committed a serious non-political crime under Article 1F(b) of the Convention and Section 322 of the Criminal Code?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 322 of the Criminal Code, Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention, Section 98 of IRPA
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Refugee claim determination and Federal Court judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant admitted taking $1 million without right or permission
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show decision was unreasonable
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Admission of unlawful taking undermined claims of lawful entitlement
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Theft under Section 322 involves taking property with intent to deprive owner; such acts constitute serious non-political crimes under refugee law
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Challenged Board's failure to consider mitigating factors like poverty and fear
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Board’s interpretation and application of law found reasonable
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Admission of theft, value exceeding $5000, absence of ownership claim
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Criminal Code and Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Asserted moral defense and necessity due to threat from mafia
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Direct admission, financial records, contextual narrative
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certify question of general importance and set aside exclusion
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed; exclusion from refugee status confirmed
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 322 of the Criminal Code, Section 98 of IRPA, Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Validity and infringement of claim 4 of Canadian Patent No. 1,304,080
Procedural_Stage: Trial and determination of validity, infringement, and remedies
Evidence_Assessment: Expert testimonies, analysis of prior art, evaluation of inventive ingenuity
Decision_Outcome: Claim 4 is valid and infringed by Novopharm Limited
Burden_of_Proof: On the party challenging the patent's validity to show invalidity
Credibility_Factor: Expert testimony credibility and technical feasibility of enantiomer separation
Legal_Rule: A patent is presumed valid unless shown otherwise; requires novelty, utility, and inventive ingenuity; obviousness assessed from perspective of a skilled person
Standard_of_Review: Whether the invention would be directly and without difficulty arrived at by a person skilled in the art
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged infringement of patent rights for S(-) Ofloxacin (levofloxacin)
Key_Evidence_Considered: Prior art, known separation techniques, Daiichi's unique pursuit of S(-) Ofloxacin, challenges in separation process
Legal_Framework: Canadian Patent Law under the 'old' Patent Act
Defendant_Response: Novopharm challenged validity of the patent, likely asserting anticipation or obviousness
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, expert reports, scientific literature
Outcome: Validity upheld, infringement confirmed, damages awarded, delayed injunction granted for sale of existing stock within 30 days
Authority: Canadian Federal Court or Supreme Court of Canada (implied by context)

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD erred in interpreting 'time of application' under paragraph 117(9)(d) of the Regulations
Crimes.Governing_Law: Paragraph 117(9)(d) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, case remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Immigration forms, declaration records
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to declare daughter’s birth during immigration process
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Ongoing obligation to update application post-initial filing
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to declare dependent after birth
Crimes.Application_Factor: Timing of disclosure relative to application process
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Error in law found, remitted for reconsideration

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to declare dependants under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Interpretation of 'at the time of application'
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD erred in limiting 'application' to initial submission
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR), paragraph 117(9)(d)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Timing of declaration of child's birth
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD decision set aside, remanded for reevaluation
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to disclose all dependants
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Obligation to disclose all family members throughout application process
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to declare newborn daughter before obtaining permanent residency
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Immigration forms, date of child's birth, timing of disclosure
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Official immigration documents, birth certificate

Risk_Assessment: Well-founded fear claimed but not established
Targeted_Victimization: No evidence of targeting based on Convention grounds
Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to establish nexus to Convention grounds
Credibility_Assessment: Not fully substantiated in legal context

Basis_for_Decision: Generalized risk, lack of Convention nexus

Prior_Criminality: Pattern of corruption and extortion by perpetrators
Targeted_Victimization: No evidence of individualized targeting beyond extortion victim

Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient to prove targeted risk or Convention link
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's account plausible but lacks legal nexus
Legal_Rule: Well-founded fear of persecution on Convention grounds required
Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution due to resistance to corruption

Legal_Issue: Exclusion from refugee status under Article 1E of the Refugee Convention
Governing_Law: Article 1E of the United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Ability to return to and receive protection from Germany
Application_Factor: No risk of deportation from Germany
Authority: United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false statements to obtain immigration benefits
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the PRRA officer fail to consider important evidence?
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No serious credibility issues identified
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Lack of supporting documents for alleged criminal charge in Romania
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Risk due to criminal charge in Romania
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant's failure to submit critical evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Burden of proof on applicant to demonstrate personal risk

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the PRRA officer fail to consider evidence or breach procedural fairness?
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No serious credibility issues found
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Absence of key evidence (article 155 charge)
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant’s abandoned refugee claim and criminal conviction
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged failure to consider evidence or hold a hearing
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Documentation related to Romanian criminal charge
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Officer not required to seek additional evidence or hold hearing without credibility concerns

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration reporting requirements
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the PRRA officer fail to consider evidence in rejecting the application?
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not applicable – decision based on lack of evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Insufficient documentary proof of personal risk
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Personal risk upon return to Romania
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Documents from Romanian authorities not submitted
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Applicant bears burden to prove risk
Crimes.Application_Factor: Abandoned refugee claim and lack of new credible evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Risk of torture or cruel and unusual treatment upon deportation.
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the PRRA officer fail to consider evidence regarding risk of torture or cruel treatment?
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Pre-removal risk assessment and judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Untrustworthy and unsubstantiated claims without documentary support
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate personal risk
Crimes.Legal_Rule: No removal if facing torture or cruel treatment (Sections 96, 97 IRPA)
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of torture due to criminal charges and poor health
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Medical condition and alleged criminal charges in Romania
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Stay of removal based on risk

Crimes.Application_Facts: Prior criminal conviction affecting immigration status
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Former refugee claimant with abandoned claim
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to criminality and medical inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Sufficiency of evidence in PRRA process
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide evidence linking possession charge to risk on return
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims not substantiated
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient evidence of personalized risk despite criminal history

Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Allegation of failure to consider evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Critical evidence not provided by applicant
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Claimed risk due to sedition charge in Romania

Dispute_Type: Denial of citizenship based on invalid adoptions
Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer correctly applied the Citizenship Act and HAMA
Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies in documents and interviews raised doubts about adoption validity
Legal_Provision: HAMA requirements: age limit, 'giving and taking' ritual, prohibition on adopting when a daughter exists
Basis_of_Claim: Adoption not compliant with Indian law
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of genuine parent-child relationship under the Citizenship Act
Application_Error: Invalid adoption due to non-compliance with HAMA
Legal_Standard: Correct application of law and procedural fairness

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Residency requirements, credibility assessment, humanitarian considerations
Crimes.Evidence_Source: Inconsistencies in testimony, lack of residency evidence
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Failure to meet 730-day residency requirement, negative credibility, lack of H&C relief

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Compliance with residency obligations and admissibility
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding due to inconsistent and evasive testimony
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimony, residency records, criminal record
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations, residency exception
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to meet residency requirement and fraudulent activities
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to IAD decision
Crimes.Application_Factor: Lack of substantial ties to Canada
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Implied by fraud and false statements

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of property obtained by crime
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether applicant met 730-day physical presence requirement
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient evidence of residency (e.g., lease agreements, employment records)
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Inconclusive tax filings and criminal record regarding presence
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Permanent resident must be physically present in Canada for 730 days in 5 years
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Tax filings, criminal record, lack of supporting documents
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Failed to provide sufficient evidence of residency
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Official records (tax, criminal), documentary evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of visa officer’s refusal

Dispute_Type: Administrative dispute over environmental protection obligations
Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister erred in failing to identify critical habitat for the Greater Sage-Grouse as required by SARA
Evidence_Assessment: Active leks and nesting/brood-rearing habitats were identifiable using existing models and data
Decision_Outcome: The Minister's decision not to identify critical habitat was unreasonable
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicants to demonstrate unreasonableness; met
Credibility_Factor: Scientific data and recovery models supporting habitat identification were credible and available
Legal_Rule: Under SARA, the Minister must identify critical habitat 'to the extent possible' based on the best available information
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to comply with statutory duty under SARA to identify critical habitat
Key_Evidence_Considered: Existence of active leks, nesting and brood-rearing areas, scientific models and habitat data
Legal_Framework: Statutory interpretation of SARA, administrative law principles
Defendant_Response: Minister argued that identifying critical habitat was not feasible due to insufficient data
Evidence_Type: Scientific data, ecological models, expert assessments
Remedy_Requested: Redrafting of the critical habitat section in the recovery strategy
Outcome: Judicial review granted; Minister required to redraft critical habitat section within a specified timeframe

Legal_Issue: Did the visa officer breach the duty of fairness in refusing the applicant's request for permanent residence as a self-employed music teacher?
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review through application for certiorari and mandamus
Evidence_Assessment: Visa officer emphasized international recognition; failed to consider other qualifications or allow applicant to address deficiencies
Decision_Outcome: Visa officer's decision was set aside
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate ability to contribute to Canada's economy or cultural life
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's qualifications as a music teacher without prior self-employment experience
Legal_Rule: Fair assessment required under Immigration Act; no mandate for prior self-employment experience
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on context of administrative decision
Grounds_for_Claim: Breach of duty of fairness by visa officer
Key_Evidence_Considered: Lack of self-employment experience, perceived inability to contribute significantly to cultural life
Defendant_Response: Refusal based on insufficient qualifications and lack of self-employment history
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, application materials, officer's assessment
Remedy_Requested: Certiorari to quash decision, mandamus to require reassessment
Outcome: Court allowed application, directed reassessment consistent with Immigration Act
Legal_Provision: Immigration Act and Regulations regarding self-employed persons
